Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Recyclable Solid Supports as a Sustainable Platform Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Award from the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows Program) Dr. Frank Leibfarth from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will develop recyclable solid supports for the efficient and economical production of complex molecules, including polysaccharides, peptides and oligonucleotides. This award has support from: the Directorate for Engineering; and the Division of Chemistry and the Division of Materials Science in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

The proposed work will combine solid phase synthesis on a polymer support with dynamic covalent chemistry with a continuous flow system to carry out the reactions that create the target molecules.

The aim of studies like that proposed in this work is to develop better, more efficient methods for the synthesis of complex molecules (e.g. pharmaceuticals) with minimum production of chemical waste.

Dr. Leibfarth will be working with collaborators Prof. Timothy F. Jamison of the Department of Chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of and Dr. Sejal Patel of Novartis Institutes of Biomedical Research. Dr. Leibfarth will also work with the MIT Office of Engineering Outreach as well as the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers on educational projects.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proteins, nucleic acids, and polysaccharides are macromolecules exquisitely designed by Nature to have diverse functions including catalysis, signaling, reinforcement, motility, and information storage. No current technology can recreate the structural fidelity of biopolymers in synthetic materials. As a consequence, synthetic polymers are traditionally used as static materials for packaging and structural support. We envisioned a new approach to the synthesis of structurally precise synthetic polymers by combining the benefits of continuous-flow chemistry and modern synthetic methods using iterative exponential growth. The semi-automated system we developed, called Flow-IEG, creates sequence-defined polymers with the fidelity necessary to begin exploring their properties for emerging applications in biomedicine, nanotechnology, and high-density information storage.

 

The Flow-IEG system performs three reactions and an in-line purification in 10 minutes, doubling the molecular weight of an oligomeric species in an uninterrupted reaction sequence with unprecedented speed and efficiency. Subsequent iterations through the Flow-IEG system enable an exponential increase in molecular weight, providing rapid access to unimolecular polymers. Introduction of monomers with alternate structures and/or branching units to the Flow-IEG system provides control over both polymer sequence and architecture. Employing this system, the synthesis of a unimolecular, sequence-defined macromolecule with a molecular weight of 4,023 g/mol has been achieved. The semi-automated feature of Flow-IEG makes it attractive for translation to non-experts in synthetic chemistry, promising that the scientists best able to study the valuable properties of structurally precise polymers will have reliable access to these materials.

 

As a further demonstration of the utility and ultimate potential of the Flow-IEG system, improvements to the framework enabled the library synthesis of monodisperse oligomers with variations in both sequence and connectivity. These discrete oligomers allowed the systematic evaluation of the consequences of monomer and triazole sequence on material properties. The crystallization properties of these macromolecules were found to be highly dependent on both their monomer sequence and triazole substitution pattern, thus highlighting the important fundamental structure–property relationships that the Flow-IEG system allowed us to study.

 

Beyond the scientific value derived from this NSF grant, the Science, Engineering, and Education for Sustainability Fellowship provided significant benefits for the development of the country’s intellectual infrastructure. Designed as a program for postdoctoral researchers, the grant enabled the Principle Investigator (PI) to pursue an intellectually challenging postdoctoral project outside of his previous area of study; thus, gaining valuable interdisciplinary knowledge and skills with the goal of maximizing the potential for innovation during his independent scientific career. This development of human resources allowed the PI to pursue cutting-edge science, mentor junior lab-mates, and ultimately resulted in the PI accepting a position as an Assistant Professor in the chemistry department at the University of North Carolina and begin an independent research group focused on upgrading plastic waste into value-added functional materials. Further, through the fellowship the PI designed a six-week laboratory course introducing the tools and concepts of continuous-flow chemistry into the undergraduate curriculum at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The course is about to begin its fourth year of implementation and over 40 students have already participated, with an expectation that the course will run six to eight years.
